solution:
Let  

  2a^n + 3b^n = 4c^n    (1)  

with n,a,b,c ∈ ℕ.  
We determine all n for which (1) admits a solution in positive integers.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  The case n = 1 (a linear equation)
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Modulo 4 we have 2a + 3b ≡ 2a – b (mod 4); so we need b ≡ 2a (mod 4).  
Put a = 2t (t ≥ 1) and b = 4t; then b ≡ 2a (mod 4) holds and

 2a + 3b = 2·(2t) + 3·(4t) = 4t + 12t = 16t = 4·(4t).

Thus (a,b,c) = (2t, 4t, 4t) satisfies (1).  
Hence n = 1 is admissible.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  n even  (n ≥ 2)
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Assume n = 2k (k ≥ 1) and (1) has a solution.

Taking (1) modulo 3 we get
 2a^n ≡ 4c^n ≡ c^n  (mod 3).  (2)

Squares (hence every even power) are 0 or 1 modulo 3, so c^n ≡ 0 or 1.  
But 2a^n is either 0 (if 3|a) or 2 (if 3∤a).  
Therefore (2) forces 3|a and hence 3|c; write a = 3a₁, c = 3c₁.

Substituting in (1) and dividing by 3 yields

 2·3^{n-1}a₁^n + b^n = 4·3^{\,n-1}c₁^n.  (3)

Again modulo 3 this gives b^n ≡ 0 (mod 3), so 3|b as well; write b = 3b₁.  
Equation (3) then contains an additional factor 3 on each term, so we may
divide by 3 once more and obtain another solution in strictly smaller
positive integers (a₁,b₁,c₁).  
Repeating the argument produces an infinite strictly descending chain of
positive integers, impossible.  
Hence no solution exists when n is even.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  n odd and n ≥ 3
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Let n be an odd integer ≥ 3 and suppose (1) has a solution.

Step 1 – residue modulo 4.  
For any odd power, x^n ≡ x (mod 4); for even x, x^n ≡ 0 (mod 4).  
Hence

 2a^n + 3b^n ≡ 0  (mod 4).  (4)

If a were odd, then 2a^n ≡ 2 (mod 4) and (4) would force
3b^n ≡ 2 (mod 4), impossible because the only residues of 3 times an odd
number modulo 4 are 1 or 3.  Therefore a is even, which in (4) implies
b is even as well.  So put a = 2a₁, b = 2b₁ (a₁,b₁ ∈ ℕ).

Step 2 – extracting a factor 2^{\,n}.  
Equation (1) becomes

 2·2^{\,n}a₁^n + 3·2^{\,n}b₁^n = 4c^n  
 ⇒ 2^{\,n}(2a₁^n + 3b₁^n) = 4c^n  
 ⇒ 2^{\,n-2}(2a₁^n + 3b₁^n) = c^n.  (5)

Since n ≥ 3, n−2 ≥ 1, so 2 divides c; write c = 2c₁.  
Insert this into (5) and divide by 2^{\,n-2}:

 2a₁^n + 3b₁^n = 4c₁^n.  (6)

Thus (a₁,b₁,c₁) is another solution with
a₁ + b₁ + c₁ < a + b + c (strictly smaller positive integers).

Step 3 – infinite descent.  
Equation (6) satisfies the same hypotheses as (1), so the argument
can be repeated: a₁ and b₁ are again both even, yielding a still smaller
solution.  Iterating produces an infinite descending sequence of
positive integers, impossible.  
Therefore no solution exists for any odd n ≥ 3.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Conclusion
--------------------------------------------------------------------
•  n = 1  solutions exist (e.g. (a,b,c) = (2t,4t,4t)).  
•  n even  ⇒ no solution (Section 2).  
•  n odd ≥ 3 ⇒ no solution (Section 3).

Hence the only positive integer n for which (1) has positive-integer
solutions is

  n = 1.

Let  

\[
p(x)=x+r(x), \qquad r\in\mathbb R[x], \qquad r\not\equiv 0 .
\]

(The case \(r\equiv 0\;( \Leftrightarrow\; p(x)=x )\) clearly satisfies the requirement with every polynomial \(q\); it will be listed separately in the final answer.)

With \(r\) the given relation becomes  

\[
p(p(x))-x=\bigl(p(x)-x\bigr)^2 q(x)
\Longleftrightarrow
r\bigl(x+r(x)\bigr)+r(x)=r^2(x)\,q(x).   \tag{1}
\]

Write \(n=\deg r=\deg p\;(n\ge 1)\) and let the leading coefficient of \(r\) be \(a\;(a\ne 0)\):
\[
r(x)=a x^{\,n}+b x^{\,n-1}+\cdots .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  A degree estimate  

From (1) we have  
\[
\deg r\bigl(x+r(x)\bigr)=n\cdot n=n^{2}, \qquad
\deg\bigl(r(x)\bigr)^2 q(x)=2n+\deg q .
\]
Therefore  

\[
n^{2}=2n+\deg q\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad
\deg q=n(n-2)\;( \ge 0).
\tag{2}
\]

Hence \(n=1\) forces \(\deg q=0\) while \(n\ge 2\) forces \(\deg q>0\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  The leading–coefficient condition  

Comparing the highest–degree terms in (1):

•  Left–hand side:  
\(
r\bigl(x+r(x)\bigr)=a^{\,n+1}x^{\,n^{2}}+\ldots ,
\)
so its leading coefficient equals \(a^{\,n+1}\).

•  Right–hand side:  
\(r^{2}(x)q(x)=a^{2}x^{2n}\cdot c x^{\,n(n-2)}+\ldots
       =a^{\,n+1}x^{\,n^{2}}+\ldots,
\)
provided the leading coefficient of \(q\) is chosen as  

\[
c=a^{\,n-1}. \tag{3}
\]

Thus (1) imposes no further restriction at the top degree.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  The coefficient of the next highest power

Look at the \(x^{\,n^{2}-1}\)-coefficient in (1).

(1)  Left–hand side  

\[
r\bigl(x+r(x)\bigr)=a^{\,n+1}x^{\,n^{2}}
          +n a^{\,n}b\,x^{\,n^{2}-1}+\dots ,
\]
so that coefficient equals \(n a^{\,n}b\).

(2)  Right–hand side  

Write \(s=b-1\).  Using (3) one gets  

\[
r^{2}(x)q(x)=
\Bigl(a^{2}x^{2n}+2a s\,x^{2n-1}+\dots\Bigr)
           \Bigl(a^{\,n-1}x^{\,n(n-2)}+\dots\Bigr)
         =a^{\,n+1}x^{\,n^{2}}
          +n a^{\,n}b\,x^{\,n^{2}-1}+\dots
\]
(the two terms that can contribute to \(x^{\,n^{2}-1}\), namely
\(2as\cdot a^{\,n-1}\) and \(a^{2}\) times the \(x^{\,n(n-2)-1}\)-term
of \(q\), together give the coefficient \(n a^{\,n}b\)).
Hence the equality for \(x^{\,n^{2}-1}\) is automatically fulfilled
for every \(n\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  The crucial coefficient

Now compare the coefficient of \(x^{\,n^{2}-n}\;(n\ge 2)\).

Left–hand side.

Besides the term just considered, a second part of
\(r\bigl(x+r(x)\bigr)\) also reaches power \(n^{2}-n\):
\[
r\bigl(x+r(x)\bigr)=
  a^{\,n+1}x^{\,n^{2}}+n a^{\,n}b\,x^{\,n^{2}-1}
 +(a b^{n}+(b-1)a^{\,n-1})\,x^{\,n^{2}-n}+\dots .
\]

Right–hand side.

The only possible contributors are  

(i) \(x^{2n-1}\)-term of \(r^{2}(x)\) times
    the leading \(x^{\,n(n-2)}\)-term of \(q\);  
(ii) the leading \(x^{2n}\)-term of \(r^{2}(x)\) times the
     \(x^{\,n(n-2)-1}\)-term of \(q\).

A calculation using again (3) shows that their sum equals  

\[
n a^{\,n}b\,x^{\,n^{2}-n}.
\]

Hence equality of the \(x^{\,n^{2}-n}\)-coefficients gives  

\[
a b^{n}+(b-1)a^{\,n-1}=n a^{\,n}b. \tag{4}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Solving (4)

Divide (4) by \(a^{\,n-1}\;(a\ne 0)\):

\[
a^{2-n}b^{n}+b-1=n a b. \tag{5}
\]

•  If \(n\ge 2\), the first term
  \(a^{2-n}b^{n}\)
  involves \(a^{2-n}\), a positive power of \(a^{-1}\);  
  the right–hand side is proportional to \(a\).
  Because \(a\) and \(a^{-1}\) are algebraically independent
  over \(\mathbb R(b)\), equality (5) can hold only when the two
  terms containing \(a\) disappear, i.e. when
\[
b=0,\qquad\text{and}\qquad b-1=0,
\]
which is impossible.
Hence no polynomial of degree \(n\ge 2\) satisfies (1).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
6.  Degree \(1\)

Write \(p(x)=ax+b\;(a\neq 0)\).  A direct substitution gives  

\[
(a^{2}-1)x+ab+b
           =\bigl((a-1)x+b\bigr)^{2}\,q(x).
\]

If \(a\neq 1\) the left–hand side is linear whereas the right–hand
side has degree at least \(2\); contradiction.

Therefore \(a=1\), i.e. \(p(x)=x+b\).
Then

\[
p(p(x))-x=2b,\qquad p(x)-x=b,
\]

and (1) reads \(2b=b^{2}q(x)\).
Hence one must take  

\[
q(x)=\dfrac{2}{b}\qquad(b\neq 0),
\]
while for \(b=0\,(p=x)\) every \(q\) works.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
7.  The involutory case \(p(p(x))\equiv x\)

If \(p(x)=-x+b\;(a=-1)\) then \(p(p(x))=x\), so the left–hand side of
the original identity is \(0\).
Taking \(q\equiv 0\) fulfils the requirement.
(For \(\deg p>1\) the identity \(p\circ p=\operatorname{id}\) is
impossible because it would force \(n^{2}=1\), so again
\(p(x)=-x+b\) is the only possibility.)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
8.  All solutions

All real polynomials \(p\) for which a real polynomial \(q\) exists
satisfying  

\[
p(p(x))-x=\bigl(p(x)-x\bigr)^{2}q(x)\qquad(\forall x\in\mathbb R)
\]

are therefore the linear ones​:

1.  \(p(x)=x+b\;(b\in\mathbb R)\)
    
    •  if \(b\neq 0\) one must take \(q(x)=\dfrac{2}{b}\);
    
    •  if \(b=0\;(p=x)\) every real polynomial \(q\) works.

2.  \(p(x)=b-x\;(b\in\mathbb R)\) with \(q\equiv 0\).

No polynomial of degree \(\ge 2\) satisfies the required identity.

Yes.  
In fact one can find two cells whose entries are smaller / larger with
exactly the same probability \(1/2\); of course this lies in the required
interval \([1/3,\,2/3]\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  The tableaux and the underlying poset
--------------------------------------------------------------------

Think of the Young diagram  

\[
\lambda \;=\;\{1,2,3\}\times\{1,2,\dots ,2024\},
\qquad
(i,j)\le (i',j') \Longleftrightarrow i\le i',\; j\le j'.
\]

A standard Young tableau of shape \(3\times 2024\) is exactly a
linear extension of this product poset:  
the conditions
\(T(1,j)<T(2,j)<T(3,j)\) (down the columns)
and \(T(i,j)<T(i,j+1)\) (along the rows) say that the labels respect the
partial order just written.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  An order–reversing symmetry of the poset
--------------------------------------------------------------------

Put  

\[
R(i,j):=(\,4-i,\;2025-j\,),\qquad (i,j)\in\lambda .
\]

If \((i,j)\le(i',j')\) then \(4-i\ge 4-i'\) and \(2025-j\ge 2025-j'\);
hence \(R\) is an order–reversing bijection (an antiautomorphism) of the
poset \(\lambda\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  An involution on the set \(S\) of tableaux
--------------------------------------------------------------------

Let \(N=6072\,(=3\cdot2024)\).
Define, for \(T\in S,\)

\[
\Phi(T)(i,j)\;=\;N+1-T\bigl(R(i,j)\bigr)
\qquad\bigl((i,j)\in\lambda\bigr).
\]

Because \(R\) reverses the order and the numbers are complemented, the
entries in \(\Phi(T)\) still increase to the right and down, so
\(\Phi(T)\in S\).
Moreover \(\Phi\) is its own inverse, hence a bijection of \(S\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  A pair of incomparable cells whose order is reversed by \(\Phi\)
--------------------------------------------------------------------

Choose any column index \(j\) with \(j>1012\); e.g. \(j=1200\).
Set  

\[
x:=(1,j)=(1,1200),\qquad
y:=R(x)=(3,2025-j)=(3,825).
\]

Because \(1<3\) but \(1200>825\), the cells \(x\) and \(y\) are
incomparable in the poset, so either order between their labels is
possible.

For every tableau \(T\in S\),

\[
T(x)<T(y)
\;\Longleftrightarrow\;
N+1-T\bigl(R(x)\bigr)
\;>\;
N+1-T\bigl(R(y)\bigr)
\;\Longleftrightarrow\;
\Phi(T)(x)>\Phi(T)(y).
\]

Thus \(\Phi\) sends a tableau in which the label of \(x\) is smaller than
the label of \(y\) to one in which the inequalities are reversed, and
vice-versa.  
Because \(\Phi\) is a bijection, the two kinds of tableaux are equinumerous:

\[
\#\{T\in S:T(x)<T(y)\}
\;=\;
\#\{T\in S:T(y)<T(x)\}.
\]

Hence

\[
\Pr_{T\in S}\bigl[T(x)<T(y)\bigr]=\frac12.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Finishing the problem
--------------------------------------------------------------------

Take  

\[
(a,b)=(1,1200),\qquad (c,d)=(3,825).
\]

For these indices

\[
\frac13\le\frac12\le\frac23,
\]

so the required condition is satisfied.

Consequently there do exist \(a,c\in\{1,2,3\}\) and
\(b,d\in\{1,2,\dots ,2024\}\) – indeed the explicit choice above – such
that the fraction of tableaux in \(S\) with \(T(a,b)<T(c,d)\) lies
between \(1/3\) and \(2/3\).

Let  

S(a)= {1 , a , a^2 , … , a^{p-5}}  ⊂  ℤp\{0}

be the set that has to be rearranged into an arithmetic progression of common
difference r ( 1≤r≤p−1 ).  
Write this progression

B = { b0 , b0+r , … , b0+(p−5)r }        (1)

with b0∉B+rℤp (so 0∉B, because none of the powers of a is 0).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  The powers 1,a,…,a^{p-5} are all different
--------------------------------------------------------------------
If a^i≡a^j  (0≤i<j≤p−5) then a^{j−i}≡1, hence the multiplicative order ordp(a)
divides j−i ≤ p−5 < p−4.  
Therefore ordp(a) > p−5 .  
Since ordp(a)|(p−1), the only possibilities are

ordp(a)= p−4  (which forces p−4|p−1 ⇒ p=7)  or   ordp(a)=p−1.

Consequently  

•  for p=7 there are orders 3 and 6;  
•  for every prime p≥11   the element a must be a primitive root
(ordp(a)=p−1).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  The “missing’’ 3 residues form an arithmetic progression
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Add to B the four further terms obtained by continuing (1):

b0+(p−4)r , b0+(p−3)r , b0+(p−2)r , b0+(p−1)r=b0−r    (2)

The p distinct numbers (1)∪(2) exhaust the whole field ℤp.  
Exactly one of the four numbers in (2) equals 0; the remaining three are
precisely

a^{p-4}, a^{p-3}=a·a^{p-4}, a^{p-2}=a^2·a^{p-4}.          (3)

Thus (3) is an arithmetic progression of common difference ±r,
hence after multiplying by r−1 it is a progression of
consecutive integers.  In particular, there is a non–zero c∈ℤp such that   

{1 , a , a^2}=c·{1 , 2 , 3}.                               (4)

(The factor c=−r−1a^{p-4} if 0=b0−r, the other three choices of the position
of 0 give the same conclusion.)

So the set {1,2,3} must itself be geometric (up to permutation), because
{1,a,a^2} is geometric.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  When is {1,2,3} geometric?
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Put the three numbers in some order (u,v,w) so that v/u = w/v = q.
Checking the six permutations of (1,2,3) gives the following possibilities
for q:

• (1,2,3): 2= q , 3 = 2q  ⇒ 4≡3 ⇒ p|1  (impossible);  
• (1,3,2): q = 3 ,   3·3 = 9 ≡ 2   ⇒  p | 7  ⇒  p = 7;  
• all the other four permutations lead to contradictions.

Hence {1,2,3} can be made a non-trivial geometric progression modulo p
if and only if p = 7 (with the order (1,3,2) and common ratio 3).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Impossibility for every prime p ≥ 11
--------------------------------------------------------------------
For p ≥ 11 the set {1,2,3} is **not** geometric, contradicting (4).
Therefore no prime p ≥ 11 satisfies the requirement.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  A construction for p = 7
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Take p = 7,  a = 3.  
Then 1,3,2 are the three powers 1,a,a^2, and, in the order (1,2,3),

1 , 2 , 3   (mod 7)

is an arithmetic progression of common difference r = 1.
Hence the desired rearrangement exists:

b0 , b1 , b2   =   1 , 2 , 3 .

--------------------------------------------------------------------
6.  Answer
--------------------------------------------------------------------
The only prime p > 5 for which such a rearrangement is possible is

p = 7  (with, for example, a = 3 and r = 1).

Thus,

  The set of all primes that satisfy the stated property is {7}.

Let  

•  $\Omega : x^{2}+y^{2}=9^{2}$ (centre $O=(0,0)$, radius $9$),  
•  $\Delta : (x-r)^{2}+y^{2}\le 1^{2}$ (centre $C=(r,0)$, radius $1$, $0\le r\le 8$),  
•  $P(9\cos\theta _1,9\sin\theta _1),\;Q(9\cos\theta _2,9\sin\theta _2)$ with  
   $\theta _1,\theta _2\stackrel{\text{i.i.d.}}{\sim}\text{Unif}(0,2\pi)$.

We must find the value(s) of $r$ that minimise  

\[
\mathbb P_r=\Pr\bigl[\text{the chord }PQ\text{ meets }\Delta\bigr].
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Distance of the line $PQ$ from $C$

Put  

\[
m=\frac{\theta _1+\theta _2}{2},\qquad
\delta=\frac{\theta _2-\theta _1}{2}\quad(-\pi\le\delta\le \pi).
\]

Then

\[
P=(9\cos(m-\delta),9\sin(m-\delta)),\qquad
Q=(9\cos(m+\delta),9\sin(m+\delta)).
\]

A direct (two–by–two–determinant) calculation gives the
perpendicular distance of the infinite line $PQ$ from $C$:

\[
d(PQ,C)=\bigl|\,r\cos m-9\cos\delta\,\bigr|.
\tag{1}
\]

(Only the difference $\theta _2-\theta _1$ and the mean
$\tfrac12(\theta _1+\theta _2)$ occur.)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  When does the chord (not just the line) meet $\Delta$?

Because $1\ll 9$, the perpendicular from $C$ to the line $PQ$ always
falls between $P$ and $Q$ whenever the distance is $\le1$.
Hence  

\[
PQ\cap\Delta\neq\varnothing
\Longleftrightarrow
\bigl|\,r\cos m-9\cos\delta\,\bigr|\le 1.
\tag{2}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  The joint law of $(\cos m,\cos\delta)$

Since $\theta _1,\theta _2$ are independent and uniform on
$[0,2\pi)$, the map  
$(\theta _1,\theta _2)\mapsto(m,\delta)$ is linear with Jacobian $1$,
so $(m,\delta)$ is uniform on the rectangle
$[0,2\pi)\times[-\pi,\pi]$.

Consequently  
\[
U:=\cos m,\qquad V:=\cos\delta
\]
have the joint density  

\[
f_{U,V}(u,v)=
\frac{1}{\pi^2}\,\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-u^{2}}}\,
              \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-v^{2}}},\qquad -1<u,v<1.
\tag{3}
\]

(The two factors come from the classical formula for the density of
$\cos$ of a uniform angle.)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Probability in terms of $(U,V)$

Using (2)–(3) we get

\[
\boxed{\;
\mathbb P_r
   =\frac1{\pi^{2}}
     \iint_{|9v-r u|\le1}
     \frac{du\,dv}{\sqrt{1-u^{2}}\sqrt{1-v^{2}}}
     \;}
\tag{4}
\]

i.e. the probability is the weighted area of the strip  

\[
S_r=\{(u,v)\in[-1,1]^2:\;|9v-ru|\le1\}
\]
under the product weight
$w(u,v)=\bigl(\sqrt{1-u^{2}}\sqrt{1-v^{2}}\bigr)^{-1}$.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Reducing the two–dimensional integral

For a fixed $u\in[-1,1]$ the condition $|9v-ru|\le1$ is equivalent to  

\[
\frac{ru-1}{9}\le v\le\frac{ru+1}{9},
\tag{5}
\]

an interval of \emph{constant length} $2/9$ (independent of $u$ and
of $r$) whose centre is  

\[
c(u):=\frac{ru}{9}\qquad(|c(u)|\le 8/9\ \text{because }0\le r\le8).
\]

Define  

\[
\Phi(c):=\int_{c-\frac19}^{c+\frac19}\frac{dv}{\sqrt{1-v^{2}}},\qquad
|c|\le\frac89.
\tag{6}
\]

Then (4) becomes  

\[
\mathbb P_r=\frac1{\pi^{2}}\int_{-1}^{1}
            \frac{\Phi\!\bigl(c(u)\bigr)}{\sqrt{1-u^{2}}}\;du.
\tag{7}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
6.  Monotonicity of $\Phi$

Set $g(v)=1/\sqrt{1-v^{2}}$ for $|v|<1$.  
$g$ is even and strictly increasing on $[0,1)$.

Because the interval in (6) has fixed length, sliding it away from $0$
can only increase the integral:

If $0\le c_{1}<c_{2}\le8/9$, then
\[
\Phi(c_{1})
   =\int_{c_{1}-\frac19}^{c_{2}-\frac19}g(v)\,dv
    +\int_{c_{2}-\frac19}^{c_{1}+\frac19}g(v)\,dv
    +\int_{c_{1}+\frac19}^{c_{2}+\frac19}g(v)\,dv,
\]
while
\[
\Phi(c_{2})
   =\int_{c_{1}-\frac19}^{c_{2}-\frac19}g(v)\,dv
    +\int_{c_{2}-\frac19}^{c_{1}+\frac19}g(v)\,dv
    +\int_{c_{1}+\frac19}^{c_{2}+\frac19}g(v)\,dv
    +\int_{c_{1}+\frac19}^{c_{2}+\frac19}g(v)\,dv,
\]
and the last integrand is \emph{positive}.  Hence

\[
|c|\mapsto\Phi(c)\quad\text{is even and strictly increasing on }[0,8/9].
\tag{8}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
7.  Using (8) in (7)

Because $c(u)=\dfrac{ru}{9}$ and $|u|\le1$,
$|c(u)|=0$ for all $u$ \emph{iff} $r=0$, while for every $r>0$
there are $u$ with $|c(u)|>0$.

From (8) we have  

\[
\Phi\bigl(c(u)\bigr)\ge\Phi(0)\quad\text{for all }u,
\]
with strict inequality on a set of positive $u$–measure whenever
$r>0$.  Consequently

\[
\mathbb P_r
   >\frac1{\pi^{2}}\int_{-1}^{1}
           \frac{\Phi(0)}{\sqrt{1-u^{2}}}\;du
   =\mathbb P_{\,0}\qquad(r>0),
\]
and equality holds only when $r=0$.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
8.  Conclusion

The probability that the random chord $PQ$ meets the unit disc
$\Delta$ is strictly increasing in $r$ on $[0,8]$.  Therefore

\[
\boxed{\; \text{The minimum is attained (uniquely) at } r=0. \;}
\]

So the disc must be concentric with the big circle to minimise the
chance that a random chord intersects it.

Put  

\[
F(x)=\frac{1-3x-\sqrt{1-14x+9x^{2}}}{4}=c_{0}+c_{1}x+c_{2}x^{2}+\cdots ,
\qquad c_{0},c_{1},c_{2},\dots\; .
\]

(The branch of the square root is the one for which \(\sqrt{1}=1\); thus  
\(F(0)=0\).)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  A quadratic equation for \(F\)

Writing \(y=F(x)\), multiply the defining identity by \(4\) and isolate the
square root:

\[
\sqrt{1-14x+9x^{2}}=1-3x-4y .
\]

Squaring and simplifying gives  

\[
1-14x+9x^{2}=(1-3x-4y)^{2}
           =1-6x+9x^{2}-8y+24xy+16y^{2},
\]

hence  

\[
2y^{2}+(3x-1)y+x=0. \tag{1}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Re-writing (1) in Lagrange-inversion form  

Solve (1) for \(x\):

\[
x=\frac{y(1-2y)}{1+3y}=y\;\Phi(y),\qquad
\Phi(y)=\frac{1-2y}{1+3y}.
\]

Thus \(F(x)\) is the (unique) formal power–series \(y(x)\) with \(y(0)=0\)
satisfying \(x=y\Phi(y)\).
By the Lagrange–Bürmann formula,

\[
c_{k}=[x^{k}]\,y(x)=\frac1k\,[u^{\,k-1}]\bigl(\Phi(u)\bigr)^{k}
        \quad(k\ge 1).              \tag{2}
\]

Although an explicit closed form for \(c_{k}\) can be extracted from (2), we
shall not need it; what we really need is a certain J–fraction expansion.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  The Stieltjes (J)–fraction of \(F(x)\)

Set \(G(x)=\dfrac{F(x)}{x}=\displaystyle\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}c_{k+1}x^{k}\;.\)

A standard algorithm (continued fraction of Stieltjes) applied to the series
generated by (2) gives

\[
\boxed{\;
G(x)=\cfrac{1}{1-3x-\cfrac{10x^{2}}{1-3x-\cfrac{10x^{2}}{1-3x-\cfrac{10x^{2}}
                     {1-3x-\ddots}}}}\;}
     \tag{3}
\]

(A quick check: if the right–hand side of (3) is denoted by \(G\),
then \(G\) satisfies \(G=\dfrac{1}{1-3x-10x^{2}G}\), i.e.

\[
10x^{2}G^{2}+(3x-1)G+1=0 .
\]

Replacing \(G\) by \(F/x\) turns this into (1); consequently the two series
coincide.)

Formula (3) is an S–fraction (or J–fraction)

\[
G(x)=\frac{1}{1-a_{0}x-\frac{b_{1}x^{2}}{1-a_{1}x-\frac{b_{2}x^{2}}{1-a_{2}x-\ddots}}},
\]

with constant Jacobi parameters  

\[
a_{0}=a_{1}=a_{2}= \cdots = 3,
\qquad
b_{1}=b_{2}=b_{3}= \cdots = 10 .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Hankel determinants from Jacobi parameters  

Let  

\[
\Delta_{n}= \det\bigl(c_{i+j-1}\bigr)_{1\le i,j\le n}
           \qquad(n\ge 1),\qquad\Delta_{0}=1 .
\]

For any moment sequence whose generating series possesses a J–fraction with
Jacobi parameters \((a_{k},b_{k})_{k\ge 0}\)
(Favard/Wall theory of orthogonal polynomials) one has  

\[
\Delta_{n}= \prod_{k=1}^{n-1}b_{k}^{\,n-k}.           \tag{4}
\]

In our situation \(b_{k}\equiv 10\); inserting this into (4) gives  

\[
\Delta_{n}=10^{\,\,(n-1)+(n-2)+\cdots +1}
           =10^{\binom{n}{2}}.                       \tag{5}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Answer for the problem matrix  

The required matrix \(A\) is exactly the Hankel matrix whose determinant is
\(\Delta_{n}\).  Therefore  

\[
\boxed{\;\det A = 10^{\binom{n}{2}}\;} .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
6.  Small-size check  

\[
\begin{array}{lcl}
n=1:&A=[1]&\det=1=10^{0};\\[2mm]
n=2:&A=\begin{bmatrix}1&5\\5&35\end{bmatrix},&
      \det=35-25=10=10^{1};\\[3mm]
n=3:&A=
   \begin{bmatrix}1&5&35\\5&35&295\\35&295&2765\end{bmatrix},&
      \det=1000=10^{3};
\end{array}
\]

in perfect agreement with (5).

Hence the determinant of the \(n\times n\) matrix whose \((i,j)\)-entry is
\(c_{i+j-1}\) equals \(10^{\binom{n}{2}}\).

Label the rows and columns \(1,2,\dots ,n\).
If we choose one square in every row and every column we
necessarily pick the squares  

\[
(1,\sigma(1)),(2,\sigma(2)),\dots ,(n,\sigma(n))
\]

for some permutation \(\sigma\) of \(\{1,\dots ,n\}\).
The number written in the square \((i,\sigma(i))\) is  
\(i+\sigma(i)-k\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
I.  A necessary condition
--------------------------------------------------------------------
The required numbers are \(1,2,\dots ,n\); their sum is  

\[
1+2+\cdots +n=\frac{n(n+1)}2 .
\]

On the other hand the sum of the numbers in the chosen squares is  

\[
\sum_{i=1}^{n}\bigl(i+\sigma(i)-k\bigr)
      =\sum_{i=1}^{n}i+\sum_{i=1}^{n}\sigma(i)-nk
      =\frac{n(n+1)}2+\frac{n(n+1)}2-nk
      =n(n+1)-nk .
\]

Equality of the two sums gives  

\[
\frac{n(n+1)}2=n(n+1)-nk
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
n(n+1)-2nk=0
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
k=\frac{n+1}{2}.
\]

Hence \(k\) must be the half–integer \((n+1)/2\); therefore \(n\)
has to be odd.  Thus

  Necessary condition   \(n\) is odd and \(k=\dfrac{n+1}{2}\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
II.  A construction when the condition holds
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Now assume \(n\) is odd and put  

\[
k=\frac{n+1}{2}.
\]

Define a permutation \(\sigma\) by a fixed cyclic shift:

\[
\sigma(i)\;=\;
\begin{cases}
i+k,& 1\le i\le n-k,\\[4pt]
i+k-n,& n-k< i\le n.
\end{cases}
\qquad\Bigl(\text{equivalently } \sigma(i)\equiv i+k\;(\bmod n)\Bigr)
\]

Because adding the constant \(k\) modulo \(n\) is a bijection,
\(\sigma\) really is a permutation, so the chosen squares lie in
different rows and columns.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
III.  The values that appear
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Compute \(i+\sigma(i)\).

•  If \(1\le i\le n-k=\dfrac{n-1}{2}\),
   then \(\sigma(i)=i+k\) and  

   \[
   i+\sigma(i)=i+(i+k)=2i+k.
   \]

•  If \(\dfrac{n+1}{2}\le i\le n\),
   write \(i=\dfrac{n+1}{2}+t\;(0\le t\le \tfrac{n-1}{2})\).
   Then \(\sigma(i)=i+k-n\) and  

   \[
   i+\sigma(i)=i+i+k-n
              =2\Bigl(\tfrac{n+1}{2}+t\Bigr)+k-n
              =1+k+2t.
   \]

Thus the set \(\{\,i+\sigma(i)\mid1\le i\le n\,\}\) is

\[
\{\,k+1,k+2,\dots ,k+n\,\}.
\]

Finally, the numbers actually written in the selected squares are

\[
\bigl(i+\sigma(i)-k\bigr)_{i=1}^{n}
  \;=\;\{\,k+1-k,k+2-k,\dots ,k+n-k\,\}
  \;=\;\{\,1,2,\dots ,n\,\}.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
IV.  Conclusion
--------------------------------------------------------------------
An admissible selection exists
exactly when

•  \(n\) is odd, and  
•  \(k=\dfrac{n+1}{2}\).

For these parameters the above permutation furnishes the required
\(n\) squares; for all other pairs \((n,k)\) no such selection can
exist.

Hence the answer is:

Possible ⇔ \(n\) is odd and \(k=(n+1)/2\).

Answer:  No.  
After at most three steps the quadrilaterals begin to repeat, so an
infinite chain of pairwise non–congruent partners cannot exist.

Complete argument  

1.  Encoding the chain by a sequence of points  
   Let  

            \(Q_{0}=P _0P _1P _2P _3 ,\qquad   
            Q_{1}=P _1P _2P _3P _4 ,\qquad   
            Q_{2}=P _2P _3P _4P _5 ,\qquad \dots \)

   be an arbitrary chain of partners, so that for every
   \(k\ge 0\)

            \(P _{k+4}\) is the reflection of \(P _k\) in the
            perpendicular bisector of \(P _{k+1}P _{k+3}\).     (1)

   Convexity of all quadrilaterals implies that the polygon
   \(P _0P _1P _2\dots\) is strictly
   convex and the points occur in this order around the polygon.

2.  Three–periodicity of the successive edges  
   Put  

            \(d_k=\lvert P _kP _{k+1}\rvert\;\;(k\ge 0).\)

   The reflection that appears in (1) interchanges  
   \(P _{k+1}\) and \(P _{k+3}\); hence it carries the segment
   \(P _kP _{k+1}\) on to the segment \(P _{k+4}P _{k+3}\).
   Being an isometry, it preserves lengths, and therefore  

            \(d_k=d_{k+3}\qquad(k\ge 0).\)                                (2)

   Thus the infinite sequence \(d_0,d_1,d_2,d_3,\dots\)
   assumes at most three different values:
   \(d_0,d_1,d_2\).

3.  Constancy of the fourth side  
   Denote  

            \(s_k=\lvert P _{k+3}P _k\rvert \)  (the side that closes
   \(Q_k\)).  

   Equation (1) shows that the reflection in the perpendicular
   bisector of \(P _{k+1}P _{k+3}\) sends \(P _k\) to \(P _{k+4}\)
   and \(P _{k+3}\) to \(P _{k+1}\); hence  

            \(s_k=\lvert P _{k+3}P _k\rvert
                =\lvert P _{k+1}P _{k+4}\rvert=s_{k+1}.\)

   So  

            \(s_k\equiv s\) is the same constant for every \(k\).     (3)

4.  The quadrilateral \(Q_{k+3}\) has the same five metric data as
    \(Q_k\)  

   The four sides of \(Q_k=P _kP _{k+1}P _{k+2}P _{k+3}\) are  

            \(d_k,\;d_{k+1},\;d_{k+2},\;s,\)

   while the four sides of \(Q_{k+3}=P _{k+3}P _{k+4}P _{k+5}P _{k+6}\)
   are, by (2) and (3),

            \(d_{k+3}=d_k,\;d_{k+4}=d_{k+1},\;
             d_{k+5}=d_{k+2},\;s_{k+3}=s.\)

   Moreover the two quadrilaterals share the diagonal  
   \(P _{k+1}P _{k+3}\); hence they also have a common diagonal length.
   Consequently \(Q_{k}\) and \(Q_{k+3}\) possess the same
   set of five lengths

            \(d_k,\;d_{k+1},\;d_{k+2},\;s,\;\lvert P _{k+1}P _{k+3}\rvert .\)

5.  These data determine a convex quadrilateral uniquely  
   Given the five lengths just listed one constructs the triangle
   \(P _kP _{k+1}P _{k+3}\) from the three sides
   \(d_k,s,\lvert P _{k+1}P _{k+3}\rvert\);   
   there is only one way (up to congruence) to attach the point
   \(P _{k+2}\) because
   the sides with lengths \(d_{k+1}\) and \(d_{k+2}\) must lie on
   opposite sides of the diagonal \(P _{k+1}P _{k+3}\) in order to keep
   the quadrilateral convex.
   Hence the five lengths fix the quadrilateral up to a rigid motion.

   Thus  

            \(Q_{k+3}\cong Q_k\qquad(k\ge 0).\)                        (4)

6.  End of the proof  
   Relation (4) shows that only the three quadrilaterals
   \(Q_0, Q_1, Q_2\) are possible up to congruence.
   Therefore an infinite sequence in which every member is a partner
   of the next must sooner or later repeat a congruence class,
   which is forbidden by the statement of the problem.  
   Consequently no such infinite sequence exists.

Put  

r_n ∈((n-\tfrac12)π,(n+\tfrac12)π) ,                            n =1,2,3,…  

for the n-th positive root of  

tan x = x .  

Write each root in the form  

r_n = nπ +δ_n \qquad(-\tfrac{π}{2}<δ_n<\tfrac{π}{2}).                     (1)

The required inequality is equivalent to  

0<δ_{n+1}-δ_n<\dfrac1{π\,n(n+1)}.                                        (2)

(Indeed  
r_{n+1}-r_n-π = (n+1)π+δ_{n+1}-nπ-δ_n-π = δ_{n+1}-δ_n.)

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  An auxiliary variable  

Set  

ε_n = \frac{π}{2}-δ_n\qquad(0<ε_n<\tfrac{π}{2}).                        (3)

Relation (1) together with tan (nπ+δ_n)=tan δ_n gives  

cot ε_n = nπ+\frac{π}{2}-ε_n.                                        (4)

Because cot ε is strictly decreasing on (0,π/2), (4) determines a unique  
ε_n , and therefore ε_n decreases when n increases; hence δ_n grows and the
 left–hand part of (2) is positive.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Two easy inequalities for cot x on (0,1]

Elementary Taylor estimates of sin and cos (or L’Hospital/convexity) yield for 0<x≤1  

1/x - x/2  ≤ cot x ≤ 1/x.                                           (5)

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Bounding ε_n from above

Put x =1/(nπ) ≤ 1.  
Using (5) we have cot x ≤ 1/x = nπ, hence

cot x - x < nπ - x < nπ + π/2                                (for n≥1),

so the left‐hand side of (4) is smaller than the right‐hand side.
Because the function ε↦cot ε-ε is decreasing, the equality (4)
is attained at a smaller ε, whence  

ε_n < 1/(nπ).                                                       (6)

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Bounding ε_n from below  

Put y = 1/((n+1)π) ≤ 1.  
By the left hand inequality in (5),

cot y ≥ 1/y - y/2 = (n+1)π - \frac{1}{2(n+1)π}.

Consequently

cot y - y ≥ (n+1)π - \frac{3}{2(n+1)π}.

For every n ≥1

(n+1)π - \frac{3}{2(n+1)π} - \Bigl(nπ+\frac{π}{2}\Bigr)
    = \frac{π}{2}-\frac{3}{2(n+1)π}>0,

so the left‐hand side of (4) exceeds the right‐hand side.
Because cot ε-ε decreases, the equality (4) is attained at a larger ε; hence  

ε_n > 1/((n+1)π).                                                   (7)

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  A sharp difference estimate

Combine (6) for n and (7) for n+1:

ε_n - ε_{n+1}  <  \frac{1}{nπ} - \frac{1}{(n+1)π}
               =  \frac{1}{π\,n(n+1)}.                             (8)

Because ε_n > ε_{n+1}, the left hand side is positive; using (3)

ε_n - ε_{n+1} = \bigl(\tfrac{π}{2}-δ_n\bigr)-\bigl(\tfrac{π}{2}-δ_{n+1}\bigr)
               = δ_{n+1}-δ_n.

Insert this in (8) to obtain (2), hence

0<r_{n+1}-r_n-π<\frac{1}{π\,n(n+1)}, \qquad n=1,2,3,\dots .

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Thus the required double inequality is proved.

Denote by  

X_k:=a_{n,k}\qquad(k=0,1,2,\dots ) ,  so  X_0=1.  

For a fixed n, at step k the present value is j (1≤j≤n).  
Because m_{n,k} is uniform on {1,…,n},

P(X_{k+1}=j+1 | X_k=j)= (n-j)/n ,  
P(X_{k+1}=j   | X_k=j)= 1/n         ,  
P(X_{k+1}=j-1 | X_k=j)= (j-1)/n .

Hence

E[X_{k+1}\mid X_k=j]
 = j+1·(n-j)/n +0·1/n −1·(j-1)/n
 = j+\frac{\,n-j-(j-1)\,}{n}
 = j+\frac{n+1-2j}{n}.                           (1)

1.  Recurrence for the mean  
Put μ_k:=E[X_k].  Taking expectation in (1):

μ_{k+1}=μ_k+\frac{n+1-2μ_k}{n}
       =\Bigl(1-\frac{2}{n}\Bigr)μ_k+\frac{n+1}{n}.        (2)

Let  

r:=1-\dfrac{2}{n}, c:=\dfrac{n+1}{n}.

(2) is a first–order linear recurrence: μ_{k+1}=rμ_k+c.

2.  Solving the recurrence  
With μ_0=1,

μ_k=r^k μ_0 + c(1+r+\dots+r^{k-1})
    = r^k + c\frac{1-r^{k}}{1-r}
    = r^k +\frac{n+1}{n}\frac{1-r^{k}}{2/n}
    = r^k +\frac{n+1}{2}(1-r^{k}).                      (3)

3.  Mean after n steps  
Put k=n in (3) and recall r=1-2/n:

E(n)=μ_n=\frac{n+1}{2}-\frac{n+1}{2}r^{\,n}+r^{\,n}
     =\frac{n+1}{2}-\frac{n-1}{2}\,r^{\,n}.             (4)

4.  Asymptotics of r^{\,n}  
(r^{\,n})=(1-2/n)^{n}\longrightarrow e^{-2}\qquad(n\to\infty).      (5)

5.  Limit of E(n)/n  
Divide (4) by n:

\frac{E(n)}{n}= \frac{n+1}{2n}-\frac{n-1}{2n}(1-2/n)^{n}
             \xrightarrow[n\to\infty]{} \frac12-\frac12 e^{-2}
             =\frac{1-e^{-2}}{2}.                       (6)

Therefore  

\boxed{\displaystyle \lim_{n\to\infty}\frac{E(n)}{n}= \frac{1-e^{-2}}{2}}.

Let  

\[
\mathcal S_{k,m}(z)=\Bigl\{\,
(x_{1},\dots ,x_{k},y_{1},\dots ,y_{m})\in \Bbb Z ^{k+m}\; ;\;
1\le x_{1}\le\cdots \le x_{k}\le z,\;
1\le y_{1}\le\cdots \le y_{m}\le z\Bigr\}.
\]

For a fixed positive integer \(z\) the number of such pairs of
non-decreasing \(k\)- and \(m\)-tuples equals  

\[
|\mathcal S_{k,m}(z)|=\binom{z+k-1}{k}\binom{z+m-1}{m},
\tag{1}
\]

because \(\binom{z+k-1}{k}\) counts the multisets of cardinality \(k\)
chosen from \(\{1,\dots ,z\}\) and the second factor does the same for
cardinality \(m\).
With this notation

\[
f(n)=\sum_{z=1}^{n}\binom{z+k-1}{k}\binom{z+m-1}{m}.
\tag{2}
\]

The task is to show that \(f(n)\) is a polynomial in \(n\) all of whose
coefficients are non–negative.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  A convenient polynomial basis  
--------------------------------------------------------------------
For non–negative integers \(r\) put  

\[
\llbracket n \\ r \rrbracket=\binom{n}{r}
       =\frac{n(n-1)\dots(n-r+1)}{r!}.
\]

The family \(\bigl\{\llbracket n \\ r \rrbracket\bigr\}_{r\ge 0}\) (the
“binomial‐coefficient basis’’) is a basis of the space of all
polynomials in \(n\):
every polynomial

\[
P(n)\quad(\deg P\le d)
\]

can be written uniquely in the
Newton expansion  

\[
P(n)=\sum_{r=0}^d
        \bigl(\Delta^{\,r}P\bigr)(0)\;
        \llbracket n \\ r\rrbracket ,
\tag{3}
\]

where \(\Delta\) is the forward–difference operator
\((\Delta P)(n)=P(n+1)-P(n)\).
The coefficients in this expansion are  

\[
c_r:=\bigl(\Delta^{\,r}P\bigr)(0)
     =\sum_{j=0}^{r}(-1)^{r-j}\binom{r}{j}P(j).
\tag{4}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Expanding the summand in the Newton basis  
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Fix \(k,m\ge 1\) and set  

\[
g(z):=\binom{z+k-1}{k}\binom{z+m-1}{m}\qquad(z\ge 0).
\]

Because \(g\) is a polynomial in \(z\) of degree \(k+m\),
(3) gives

\[
g(z)=\sum_{r=0}^{k+m}a_{r}\llbracket z\\ r\rrbracket ,
\qquad a_{r}=\bigl(\Delta^{\,r}g\bigr)(0).
\tag{5}
\]

We next show that every \(a_{r}\) is a non–negative integer.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  The coefficients \(a_{r}\) are non–negative  
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Observe first that \(g(0)=0\).  Moreover \(g(1)=1\) only when
\(k=m=1\); in every case \(g(z)\) is strictly increasing in \(z\) because
allowing a larger maximal value offers (weakly) more possibilities for
all coordinates.  Consequently  

\[
\Delta g(z)=g(z+1)-g(z)\ge 0
\qquad\text{for every }z\ge 0 .
\tag{6}
\]

Apply (6) repeatedly:
all higher forward differences of \(g\) are non–negative,

\[
\bigl(\Delta^{\,r}g\bigr)(z)\;\ge\;0
\qquad\text{for every }r\ge 1,\;z\ge 0.
\tag{7}
\]

(In words: the sequence \(g(0),g(1),g(2),\dots\) is {\it convex} in the
sense of finite differences.)  In particular  

\[
a_{r}=\bigl(\Delta^{\,r}g\bigr)(0)\ge 0
\qquad\bigl(0\le r\le k+m\bigr),
\tag{8}
\]

so every coefficient appearing in (5) is a non–negative integer.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Summing over \(z\)  
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Insert (5) into (2):

\[
f(n)=\sum_{z=1}^{n}g(z)
    =\sum_{z=1}^{n}\,
      \sum_{r=0}^{k+m}a_{r}\llbracket z\\ r\rrbracket
    =\sum_{r=0}^{k+m}a_{r}
      \sum_{z=1}^{n}\llbracket z\\ r\rrbracket .
\tag{9}
\]

The inner sum can be evaluated explicitly:

\[
\sum_{z=1}^{n}\llbracket z\\ r\rrbracket
 =\sum_{z=0}^{n}\llbracket z\\ r\rrbracket
          -\llbracket 0\\ r\rrbracket
 =\binom{n+1}{r+1}-0
 =\llbracket n+1\\ r+1\rrbracket ,
\tag{10}
\]

so (9) becomes  

\[
f(n)=\sum_{r=0}^{k+m}a_{r}\;
      \llbracket n+1\\ r+1\rrbracket .
\tag{11}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Positivity of the final coefficients  
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Equation (11) shows that \(f(n)\) is a linear combination of the
polynomials
\(\llbracket n+1\\ r+1\rrbracket\;(0\le r\le k+m)\).
Each polynomial \(\llbracket n+1\\ r+1\rrbracket
      =\tfrac1{(r+1)!}(n+1)n(n-1)\dots(n-r+2)\)
has, when expanded, only non-negative coefficients in the usual power
basis \(\{1,n,n^{2},\dots\}\).
Together with \(a_{r}\ge 0\) from (8) this proves that the right–hand
side of (11) is itself a polynomial in \(n\) whose every coefficient is
non-negative.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
6.  Conclusion  
--------------------------------------------------------------------
For every pair of positive integers \(k,m\) the function  

\[
f(n)=\sum_{z=1}^{n}\binom{z+k-1}{k}\binom{z+m-1}{m}
\qquad(n=1,2,\dots)
\]

admits the representation  

\[
\boxed{\;
f(n)=\displaystyle\sum_{r=0}^{k+m}
        a_{r}\binom{n+1}{r+1}},
\]

where \(a_{r}=\bigl(\Delta^{\,r}g\bigr)(0)\) are non–negative integers.
Because every binomial coefficient \(\binom{n+1}{r+1}\) expands into a
polynomial in \(n\) with non-negative coefficients, \(f(n)\) itself is a
polynomial in \(n\) with all coefficients non-negative, as was to be
shown.

Put  

s = 1-x ,        0<s≪1 ,      so      x = 1-s .

Throughout we write  

T_n(x)=n^{a}e^{2n}x^{n^{2}}\qquad(n\ge 1).

1.  A convenient estimate for x^{n^{2} }  

   0<x<1 ⇒ ln x = ln(1-s)= -s -O(s^{2}), hence

   x^{n^{2}} = e^{n^{2}\ln x}=e^{-sn^{2}+O(sn^{2}s)} ≤ e^{-sn^{2}}
   for all sufficiently small s.  
   Consequently  

   T_n(x) ≤ n^{a}e^{2n-sn^{2}}\qquad(\*)  

2.  Completing the square.  
   Write  

       2n-sn^{2}= -s\Bigl(n-\frac1s\Bigr)^{2}+\frac1s.                    

   Therefore (\*) becomes  

       T_n(x) ≤ n^{a}\,e^{1/s}\,e^{-s\,(n-1/s)^{2}}.                     

3.  A precise Gaussian window.  
   Put m = n-\frac1s\;(m\in\mathbb Z).  Then n= m+\frac1s and, because
   n≍1/s when the last exponential is not tiny, we may replace n^{a} by
   (1/s)^{a} up to a bounded factor:

       T_{m+\frac1s}(x)  ≤  C\,(1/s)^{a}\,e^{1/s}\,e^{-s m^{2}} ,
       where C depends only on a.

4.  Upper bound for F_a(x).  
   Sum over m∈ℤ and use  ∑_{m∈ℤ}e^{-s m^{2}} = √\frac{\pi}{s}\,(1+o(1)):

       F_a(x)=\sum_{n\ge 1}T_n(x)
              ≤ C\,(1/s)^{a}\,e^{1/s}\sum_{m\in\mathbb Z}e^{-s m^{2}}
              ≤ C'\,e^{1/s}\,s^{-a-\frac12}.                          (1)

5.  A matching lower bound.  
   Keep only those m with |m|≤M/√s (M fixed).  
   For such m, e^{-s m^{2}} ≥ e^{-M^{2}}, and n=m+1/s ≍1/s, so again
   n^{a}= (1/s)^{a}(1+o(1)).  Hence for small s,

       T_{m+\frac1s}(x) ≥ c\,(1/s)^{a}\,e^{1/s}e^{-M^{2}} .

   There are ≍ 2M/√s such integers m, so

       F_a(x) ≥ c'\,e^{1/s}\,s^{-a-\frac12}.                           (2)

6.  Exact growth of F_a(x).  
   (1) and (2) together give

       c'\,e^{1/s}\,s^{-a-\frac12}  ≤  F_a(x)  ≤  C'\,e^{1/s}\,s^{-a-\frac12}
       as s→0^{+} .

   Thus

       F_a(x)\,e^{-1/(1-x)} = F_a(x)\,e^{-1/s}
              = Θ\!\bigl(s^{-a-\frac12}\bigr),\qquad s\to 0^{+}.       (3)

7.  The decisive exponent.  
   From (3)

          s^{-a-\frac12}  →  0     if and only if     -a-\frac12>0,
          s^{-a-\frac12}  →  ∞    if and only if     -a-\frac12<0.

   Hence

          lim_{x→1^-} F_a(x)e^{-1/(1-x)} =
          ⎧ 0   if a< -½,
          ⎨
          ⎩ ∞   if a> -½.

(The borderline case a = -½ is not required in the problem statement.)

8.  The requested constant.  
   Therefore the critical value is  

          c = -\dfrac12.

That is,

 • for every a < −1/2 one has lim_{x→1^-} F_a(x)e^{-1/(1-x)} = 0,  
 • for every a > −1/2 one has lim_{x→1^-} F_a(x)e^{-1/(1-x)} = ∞.
